So let's continue our journey
into the image compression.

The next few lectures will be
a little bit more advanced. We won't have any specific
homeworks on them,

but please try to take in as
much as you can in the class.

Be participative,
have discussions around it, and everything, OK?

Cool. Let's get started. So just a quick recap, like,
what is an image, right? So you have an array
of pixels, which

is, like, this height,
width, and channels. And typically, you
would have-- you will store, like, each
of these values as,

like, 1 byte or sometimes
10 bits or 12 bits, right?

And then we looked
at, like, what happens when you do image compression. So it has been, I
guess, a long week's

break, so I'm just
going to reproduce these slides from the last
time just so that you guys can refresh what we saw.

And so this is a raw image. And this takes like 1.1
megabyte, uncompressed.

And if you compress
it using JPEG by 40x, so this file becomes,
like, 27 kilobytes.

And if I go back and
forth, you don't really see any difference. So lossless-- sorry, lossy
image compression with JPEG

seems to be doing fine. But now, like, we have studied
about the rate distortion. So you can ask
the question like,

what happens if I
keep compressing it further and further? So if you compress it
further at this point, you can start seeing
some noticeable artifacts

in the image. So this file is at
14 kB at this point, but you can see quite a high
distortion so as to say, right?

And if you go even
further, if you try to compress this to, like,
by two orders of magnitude, 8 kilobytes, now this picture
is completely unrecognizable.

And then we saw last
class that-- oh, but-- and we learned a lot about JPEG
like how JPEG exactly works.

But then towards the end, we
also just briefly touched upon, like, why JPEG is like-- there are many places
where JPEG can be improved.

Like JPEG is not really
an upper bound so as to say in terms of performance. And we learned something about
[? a ?] compressor called BPG.

What BPG does is just allows you
to have variable block sizes as well as predictive coding.

And we had a quiz question
on predictive coding just to get you guys practice. Like I said, it's nothing
tough, just very obvious steps.

And so if you compare the
performance of JPEG with BPG, so now both of them
are at 8 kilobytes.

But as you can see like--
oops, OK. yeah, as you can see,

there's, like, a big difference
in the reconstructed image, right? So obviously, like, JPEG can
be improved by quite a lot.

It's very obvious. But BPG still uses, like, a
lot of hand-tuned parameters.

And we'll come to
that in a second. And that's what today's
lecture is going to be about. Like how can you go
even beyond, like,

the traditional
image compressors? So with this revision
just to go over, like, the quiz
questions quickly,

so the first question
was just, like, trying to understand, like,
the same basic principles.

I would say just go over the
solution in your free time. It's, like, quite
straightforward,

the answers for the first three. It's just like literally
doing this weight times

height times number
of bytes math, but now we added
an alpha channel to make things more interesting.

And then the last question
was somewhat interesting, which is like in this
question, we saw that PNG still seems to perform better than
even if you were using just one

bit for color and one
bit for alpha channel, but it seems like all the
best you can do in this case. And the question asks like, why?

And we didn't really talk
about PNG in the class. The idea was to-- now
you know about JPEG.

I was to guess how you can do
even better, why this lossless compressor is performing
so much better.

And there are lots
of correct answers, but the just basic idea
what we were looking for--

or anything is fine-- is that
PNG basically does much better entropy coding than JPEG.

Recall JPEG was just
doing a basic run length encoding plus Huffman
encoding, but we know that you can do--
you can do better.

And in this case, it's like a
really, really uniform image. So PNG, which uses actually
an LZ77-based lossless

entropy coder, can perform
very well because it gets you a lot of matches. So if you look back to
your homework three Pokémon

question, right, so that's
really the intuition. It's the same
intuition at play here.
OK, any questions?

Good. And then in the
second question, we made this JPEE274G
compressor, right?

And the idea was really to
work through some of the design decisions like what we
talked about in the class.

The first question was
around like, when would you think increasing the block size
gives you the more benefit?

And the main intuition
there is that when you have the same image,
and you are representing it

in much higher
resolution, that means you have more number
of pixels representing the same information,
and hence there

is lesser correlation between
neighboring pixels, right? And so when you
expand the block size,

you will be able to capture
more correlation between pixels within a block size.

And that's how DCT works,
and it really helps you. And so the answer
for the first one was basically like you
expect to see more benefits

for the image with
higher resolution as you increase the block size.

And then the second question
was now on like, OK-- so OK, the first question--
the idea was like,

what happens within
a block, right? We were trying to see how
the correlations work out within a block.

The second question
was like, OK, now, we said that this
compressor also

uses prediction of blocks based
on previously encoded blocks. So now, instead of just looking
at pixels within a block,

we are trying to see if
the neighboring blocks and everything-- are they
predictive of the next block?

And again, the idea really is if
you can do a better prediction, then you can use that prediction
to have lower residuals

and compress your stream
much better, right? This is exactly the two
ideas which BPG also uses

to improve upon JPEG, right? So it allows you to
have bigger block sizes, and it also allows you
to have prediction.

And so the idea there
really was that, oh, if you have more homogeneous
blocks, if your image is really

consisting of very
similar looking blocks, you can do better predictive
coding because it's probably

just a copy, paste. So in this Charizard
image, you'll probably have blocks,
which are basically

all same color versus
this assorted Pokémon image, which has lots
of things happening, OK?

So this is basically,
again, the ideas of how BPG improves in some
sense compared to JPEG.
Any questions?

No? Cool. And then the third question
was around predictive coding.

So we described an algorithm
for predictive coding. In class, I just
mentioned that we'll do-- predictive coding
is not that hard.

So if you work
through this question, you hopefully
understand the algorithm for doing predictive coding.

And then we gave just,
like, two questions, one on decoding and one
on finding the errors.

And I think it's
quite straightforward. But if you didn't understand,
just go through this and reach out to us in
the office hours using it.
OK.  Cool. Any questions in the--

so far on image
compression or quizzes?

Nope. OK, great. So let's continue. OK, again, JPEG at
8 kilobytes-- this

is the reconstructed
image, which you get BPG at 8 kilobytes,
super better than what JPEG is.

But if you look at
it carefully, like, you still see some
artifacts, right? Like you see some
blockiness in this nose,

similarly here, some
ringing stuff, right? So this is what you
get with ML-based image

compression, again, at 8
kilobytes, OK, same file size. And so if I go back and
forth between BPG and this,

can you see the difference? So it's quite-- maybe if
you look at the girl's eye, I think--

oops, sorry.  So it's quite drastic, right? So the point really is OK,
BPG is also not the same.

Like it's not really
an upper bound. You can still
perform much better. And again, if you have to
really take a stark contrast,

this is what JPEG
reconstruction looks at, same file size versus-- this is what an ML-based
reconstruction looks.

So there's clearly a lot
of room for improvement. OK, and so today we'll be
learning more about how do you,

like, employ ML and deploy
it for the use of image compression particularly.

OK, so just a reminder, this is
what our pipeline for the JPEG

looked like. And we have seen similar things
over the past few classes, so now you should be
comfortable with the ideas.

You start with something LGB. You do color treatment. This is mostly to decorrelate
the natural signals.

And then we do, I would say,
a vanilla lossy compressor

pipeline, which is, first,
you do some transform to decorrelate your components. Then you do quantization.

Finally, you do some lossless
encoding, some entropy coding, and that gives you
your JPEG file, right?

And we went into
details of each of these components last lecture.

So now the question
is, like, how can we improve this
even further, OK? So the first idea really
is, like, maybe we

can go beyond linear transform. So if you saw, like, JPEG,
JPEG2000, BPG, all of these

uses some variants
of discrete cosine transform, discrete
wavelet transform, discrete Fourier transform.

But all of these transforms
are just linear maps. It's a matrix multiplication. Maybe we can do
something better if we

allow for some nonlinear
transform coding to take place, which we haven't
studied in class at all so far,

right? And so this is really the idea. So think of these plots as
the two-dimensional vector

coding which we have looked at. So x-axis is just some
source dimension one. Y-axis is the source dimension
two so like x1, x2 things

which we have been looking at. These purple dots are
the codebook vectors, and the regions are the
codebook boundaries.

And let's say your density
function, the actual source which you are encoding, is
in this banana kind of shape,

where yellow color means
higher probability density, and blue color means
less probability density. And so if you were to
vector quantize this block,

and you are only
allowed to do, like, linear boundaries with
this vector transform,

this is probably the best
you can do to capture this. But if you were allowed
nonlinear boundaries,

then I can exactly
cover this vanilla-- sorry, this banana
peel kind of shape. And I only need to transmit
these few vectors, right?

And you can be much
more efficient. Sorry, only these few
codebook vectors here, right?

And so in this very trivial,
like, synthetic example, you can already see that if your
PDF of real sources-- nobody

said they have to follow
some linear boundaries, or they can be
linearly decorrelated. Maybe there is some
nonlinear transform
which decorrelates them. So that's one.

The other idea is really more
related to ML, which is-- so in JPEG, we saw
there were, like,

lots of these hand-determined
heuristics, right? Like we had these quantization
matrices which were like--

which just came out of nowhere. These were, like,
specific numbers. When I say nowhere, it
isn't really nowhere.

We motivated it
based on NLG and lots of psychovisual experiments. But nobody said, like,
these quantization matrix

is the best one for your image
or your particular data set. Similarly, there were, like,
other design decisions like 8

by 8 block size, why
not more, for example. And so there are lots
of heuristics involved

during the design of JPEG. A lot of smart people
really, over the years, like, fine-tune each
small knob to optimize

every bit, which contributes
and goes into JPEG, right? But this is really hard, right?

Also, like, if we think
about R-D optimization, which we actually didn't
talk about much-- but somehow we have to do this.

We have to trade off
rate with distortion. And the way you do it in JPEG
is by changing your quantization matrix, right?

And again, like,
this changed also. So not only the values
which were determined for one particular
rate distortion,

but the change between
different rates and distortion, the trade-offs between
rate and distortion were also
hand-determined, right?

And there is no way really
to know that that is optimal. And so one question
really is, can we

motivate this decision in
a more end-to-end fashion? When I say end-to-end
fashion, like in some way

to determine these way like--
to determine our compressor algorithms or the exact
weights depending on,

like, the final
value of the rate, distortion somehow figure
that out backwards.

And if you know ML, you know
what I mean by really end to end, right? So the whole premise
of ML is like you

try to do this end-to-end
learning for whatever you

are trying to optimize. And so these are
basically, I would say,

the two main motivation and
ideas for learned compression.

Like learned compression just
means using machine learning. And it goes beyond all these
traditional compressors

by going beyond, first of all,
linear-to-nonlinear transform and then also doing this
end-to-end training.

And there has been,
like, a ton of work, I would say, in just past. I would say the one
of the early papers

by Toderici in CVPR15
and Theis in ICLR17-- like those were the first
papers which started

using ML for compression. But since then, there have been
like lots and lots of work. Basically, it's a
really hot field.

A lot of people
are contributing. And hopefully, by the
end of this lecture, I can convince you that it's
a really important topic

to learn if you want to-- if you want to
continue in compression and keep contributing. At least you should know about
the techniques and ideas.

It's also very interesting
because there is a whole CLIC Challenge. It's called Challenge on
Learned Image Compression, which

is I think in its fourth
or fifth iteration now. And this is happening at
Data Compression Conference.

And this is a really active
channel, a lot of industry, a lot of people,
a lot of academia participate in this to come
up with the best compressors

for images and videos right? So if-- after this class,
I hope you should also

be prepared if you
would like to take participate in
challenges like this.

OK, so lots of-- another point which
I want to make-- like lots and lots of
interesting works and ideas

will only focus on the basic
ideas like the fundamentals. And then you can go
on and in future,

read whichever of these papers
you want to build on them.

Cool. Everyone with me? [INAUDIBLE] OK, so before I go
into learned image compression,

since we decided we'll
not assume any background, next few slides might
be boring for people

who are already aware about ML. But if you don't know
anything about ML, just hear through the
next five minutes.

And hopefully, you
should have everything which you need to
know or at least appreciating today's lecture
with regards to compression.

But if you already know
it, don't worry about it. So this is really 101,
thousand feet review, right?

There are lots and lots of
interesting classes which you can take, which will
teach you in much more depth,

and I'll encourage
you guys to do that. But there are three main
components to any ML pipeline,
really. The first is data, right? So you try to figure out--

you try to optimize some
problem based on the data which you have been given. The second is some
nonlinear model

and differentiable
architectures, which is this f of x, which
is a predictor basically

on your data. So you can think of
x as your data inputs and y as your labels.

Let's look at some examples. For example, your
x can be images. Y can be whether it is
a dog or cat or not.

So y can be a binary
label per image saying, OK, whether there is a dog
in this image or not, right?

So your nonlinear model
or your function f is basically trying to learn.

It's trying to predict
whether there is a cat or not in your image. So it's a function of
the input data x image.

And typically, it is a
parameterizable model. What that means is it
typically has-- it's defined

based on some parameters theta. The standard notation for
this is something like this. All that means is like--

OK, if you recall a
rate-distortion water-filling thing, water-filling
formula, there also we had a theta, which was
a parameter to parameterize

a rate-distortion curve. Think of theta in the same way. Basically, your function f just
depends on parameter theta.
And it takes input x, OK? The output of this is y hat.

Now, your y hat can be-- it can be involved, but
for now, think of it as--

what your model
thinks is the label for this particular image, OK? So maybe based on
whatever model I have,

when I input a particular
image, it thinks it's a cat. And it was indeed a cat. Or maybe it says it's dog, even
though the input image is cat.

So it's figuring out
based on this whatever function f on data
and parameters

to get this prediction y hat. And this is really the second
main component of our pipeline.

And the final main one
is the loss function. So you need to
determine like, OK,

so if my model predicts some
cat or dog, whether it's correct or not, right? So if given an image,
my model predicts cat,

one of the loss functions could
really be just a 1 hat, right? So you can just decide
if it's an indicator, so

if the predicted value is
cat, whether it is indeed cat or not, given the
original input label y.

OK, so very, very
high level overview. Mostly all of you are already
aware of this in today's world

and age, but start
from here, OK?

And then the way this
ML pipeline really

works is your f can
be anything, right? It's just a nonlinear
differentiable architecture.

It could be thousand
different things. But the basic idea is you use
backpropagation or gradients

to actually learn the
model parameters theta. And that's how you--
that's what's called

training or learning, right? And that happens based
on whatever given data you have like x and y.

The way this
progresses is by taking gradients of your loss function
with respect to theta, OK?

So here, all I
have done is like-- remember our loss was just-- it tells you whether you were
correct or not with respect

to the label, which
was given to you based on the predicted label. Here, I've just replaced
my predicted label

by f, X of theta, which is
what that prediction really is. And what you want
to do is you want

to minimize this loss function. So this is an
optimization problem. You want to figure out
parameters theta, which

basically minimizes your loss. So you want to train
your model or parameters so that your overall
objective function reduces,

which is this loss function. And the way you reduce this-- so
this is a general optimization

problem. So if you know about
convex optimization and non-convex
optimization, this

is, like, maybe easy to solve,
maybe hard to solve typically in our modern day machine
learning and world.

It's typically a non-convex
optimization problem, and so it's really hard to
solve this problem exactly.

But what you can do is you can
do a vanilla gradient descent. What that means is that you
update the parameters theta

at each time step by taking a
gradient with respect to theta of this loss function.

OK? And you keep doing
this repeatedly, and that basically updates
your parameter theta

and gets it to a point so as
this optimization function

is really-- this objective function
is really optimized. So you are minimizing the
loss, or you are basically

finding a model f, which is
giving you the correct labels y.

OK? So if you are seeing
this for the first time, are you with me?

Is there any questions? Are there any questions? So this is, like, the basic
training architecture like what

you are really trying to do. All you are trying
to do is you are trying to find a model, which
takes an input from data

x, outputs a
prediction label y hat. The way you are trying to find--
you are trying to find out

this model is instead of, OK,
maybe doing DFT, DCT, blah, blah, blah, some
hand-driven model,

you are trying to
learn this model using the data which you have. The way you learn it is you need
to define this loss function,

which basically
tells you difference between the actual labels. So is it actually cat
or not versus predicted

labels, which is what
your model is saying. And then you backpropagate it
or optimize this loss function

using-- by passing gradients
through the network. And that updates your
model parameter theta

eventually leading in reduction
of this loss function.

OK, and so again, like
there are a lot of-- I'm trying to summarize
this in five minutes

like a lot of details and like-- yeah, I'm not sure if
it's helpful or not, but there are a lot
of classes which

goes into much more details. Do check it. But this is
basically the summary at the very least which you need
to understand and appreciate

to understand today's class. So the first thing
is, in ML, you

use data to learn
the model parameters for optimizing a loss. So these are the three
things which we wanted to--

the three main components
which are there in your machine learning pipeline. You do this by taking
gradients of your loss function

with respect to theta. And your losses now-- it depends on the theta
because your prediction

depends on the theta. OK? And the main
advantage it provides over this non-learned
models is really,

it allows optimizing essentially
any objective function loss

as long as your function
is differentiable, OK? What that means is so as to
be able to do these gradients,

you should be able
to take this-- you should be able-- your
loss should be differentiable.

And that typically means
like if your f consists of multiple layers, you should
be able to differentiate through them.

It's basic application
of chain rule. And again, I know like, go
check out this if you are not

following it completely. If you don't know about
it, trust me on this. You need the layers to
be differentiable so as

to be able to do any learning. What that means for us is
that it doesn't play well

with discrete
distributions, right? So our whole
lossless compression has worked with some
discrete distributions.

And so you can't just
like go and backpropagate or fit in a standard
machine learning model

and get a learned
compressor because you have to somehow deal with
the discreteness part of the entropy coder.

The second main advantage is
that it allows you stacking of these nonlinear layers.

So your model f need not
be linear anymore, OK? What is a linear model?

It's basically multiplication--
it's just a matrix, right, a matrix multiplication.

And if you think about it like
stacking of linear layers-- so going back to your
linear algebra again.

Stacking of linear layers
is basically not so powerful because if you were
multiplying three, or four,

or whatever number
of matrices together, you could just represent this
as a single matrix, right?

So if you had ABC,
whatever, stacked matrix, it still gives you--
you can represent it

as a single matrix. So it's not really giving
you any more expressivity in your model, whereas if
you have nonlinear layer,

and then you stack them,
then this is no longer true. And that's really the second
main benefit of this ML.

That's why if you have ever
heard about deep neural nets, and like let's-- we went from billion parameters
to million parameters

to billion parameters to
hundred million parameters. And the way we do it is keep
on increasing the depth, and we need more data.

All of these are very punchlines
you keep hearing outside. All of them have basically
got to do with this idea that

in machine learning-- or sorry,
in-- yeah, in linear case, there is no advantage of,
like, stacking linear layers,

but in a nonlinear case, there
is a lot of advantage of, like, stacking linear layers--
oh, sorry, nonlinear layers.  Cool. Any questions?

So this is just like an overview
of a standard ML pipeline. Finally, this is
the last thing which

we need for today's lecture. Again, you don't
have to worry if you haven't seen this before.

But there is another
architecture called autoencoder architecture. And the idea really is
that you have some input x.

So this is the same input, OK? This whole thing
you can think of it as your model like the-- sorry.

Yeah, so I was saying so
now, the last thing which you need to know to appreciate
this lecture from ML

is this idea from
autoencoder architecture. Just really so now
you have some input x.

You can think of this
encoder/decoder pair as your model. And that outputs your
y or x dash here, which

is the reconstructed input. OK, so the main idea
here really is that-- so in our typical
pipeline, we also

needed the true labels,
so whether it's a cat or not, right? But the idea of this
autoencoder architecture

really is you try to
recover an output which is similar as the input.

OK, and then your loss
function can be determined such that you basically want your
x dash to be similar to x.

So your loss function
can be over x and x dash. So you can think you
start with an image. You make it go through
some architecture, which

we'll come to in a second. This is your f, X of,
in this case, theta phi, which are the parameters.

And then the output
is just x dash. And then your loss function
will be over some x and x dash.

So you start with an image. You recover an image, right? The way you do it is
that your model actually

has a very specific
architecture where you first have an encoder, which reduces
the dimension of your input

to something small,
this bottleneck z. And then using that bottleneck
z, you try to decompress it.

So you have
something which tries to increase the
number of parameters and bring it back
to the image, OK?

Does this architecture
remind you of something?

They hint us like this. Look at the words
with respect to z.

OK, come on. Yeah, so this is exactly
in some-- not exactly, but this is in some sense very
similar to compression problem,

right? So what you are trying to do
is you are forcing your network to learn an encoder
and a decoder pair--

so these parameters
phi and theta-- such that whatever this
low-dimensional bottleneck is,

which is typically called
the latent variables, you are able to recover an
image from that or x dash

from that, which looks very
similar to the original input. This is exactly what we want
in some sense in compression,

right? Like what JPEG does is you
start with that input images, x. You want some
low-dimensional bitstream

or not-- actually, there is no
low dimensional, no continuous thing there. But you basically want
to represent this image

in terms of as few number
of bits as possible, which is, like, your bottleneck. And then you start with that
bottleneck like few bits

and try to recover back
an image, which looks very similar to the original one.

OK, so this is a very
popular architecture called autoencoder architecture. And again, there are hundred--

tens of fundamentals variants
of it and then hundreds of more variants on top of
each of these tens of variants.

So it's a very, very
popular architecture. But the idea really
is you are trying to learn parameters,
such that you

compress so as to say whatever
original input you start with. And then you
decompress to get back

something which is original. And you do try to learn this
in an end-to-end fashion. You determine a loss
over this x and x dash.
Cool. Everyone with me?

Huh? So now, let's get into our-- again, the image compression
problem, so same thing

what we looked at, but now
in words and terminologies which we understand and how we
have looked into this problem.

So let's say you have some
target image like these cats. What do you want to do
is you want to encode it.

That's your encoder
to some bitstream. And then using
this bitstream, you want to decode it and get
some target reconstruction

like I hat. And the goal really is to do
this R-D optimization, right? So you want to
minimize the distortion

between original image and
the reconstructed image given some constraint on
the rate, which is just

the length of this bit should
be less than or equals to B. OK, so this is what you
really want to achieve

at the end of the day. And so in traditional
image codecs,

essentially, the encoding was
working in three steps, right? So we first did DCT. And earlier, we call this
symbol something else,

but for this talk,
let's call it z. And the reason is we're
going to correlate it back to these latent variables.

It's a very commonly
used symbol z for it. So first step was
DCT to decorrelate.

The second step is
quantization, right? So this is where the
loss gets introduced like loss of precision.

And then you would do
some arithmetic encoding on these discrete symbols, let's
say, or your favorite lossless

entropy coder for that purpose. For this talk, let's assume
you do arithmetic encoding. The idea you do arithmetic
encoding is now,

you can assume that
your length of bits is approximately equal
to log 1 over P of z hat. And again, we have looked into
this through many homeworks

and classes. So I am hopeful now this
idea is really, deep down, you guys understand it.

OK. And so then what happens
on the decoder side-- you start with this bits. You do decoding, which
basically gives you

these discretized
latent variables z hat. And now you do directly
